questions.explanation:
Solution:

Equinus,inversion,forefoot adduction,cavus CTEV is a congenital malformation of the foot. Predominantly seen in male children. In congenital talipes equinovarus (CTEV), or clubfoot, the deformity is equinus, inversion, forefoot adduction, and cavus. Components of deformity Cavus - This deformity occurs due to exaggerated arching of the foot at the midtarsal joint. Adduction - This deformity occurs at the talonavicular joint. Inversion - This deformity occurs at the subtalar joint. The calcaneum is inverted, and along with it, the whole foot is inverted. This leads to a medially facing sole. Equinus - This deformity occurs at the ankle joint and tarsal joints.

Highyeild:

Ponseti Method : Should begin as early as 2 weeks The order of correction according to Ponseti's method is cavus-adduction-varus-equinus (CAVE) . Weekly manipulation of the foot is done with the help of plaster casts. First metatarsal is elevated to correct the cavus , creating a flat longitudinal medial border of the foot. Then the forefoot is abducted in the plane of the metatarsals , everts the hindfoot and corrects the forefoot out of supination. Finally, the equinus is corrected by dorsiflexing the foot at the ankle joint . A percutaneous Achilles' tenotomy is required later for complete correction of the equinus deformity. In addition to the above procedure, the child can be provided with CTEV shoes once the child starts walking to retain correction.

Table:

#MANTRA AGE WISE MANAGEMENT OF CTEV Initial treatment starts with Ponseti's POP cast as early as possible,but within 1 year of age.

questions.text: A 35 year old man presented with knee pain. The x-ray of his knee joint is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Osteoclastoma The given clinical scenario and the x-ray showing a lytic lesion at the end of a long bone with a soap-bubble appearance suggest a giant cell tumor (GCT)/ osteoclastoma. Osteoclastoma usually affects young adults of age 20 to 40 years with slight female predominance. It is a benign but locally aggressive tumor. It is exclusively seen in adults and affects the ends of long bones, involving metaphysis/ epiphysis of long bones. GCT is most commonly seen in the distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus, and distal radius. Common presenting complaints are swelling and vague pain. Sometimes, the patient presents for the first time with a pathological fracture through the lesion. Important x-ray features of a GCT: A solitary, possibly loculated, lytic lesion in the epiphysis. Eccentric location, most often subchondral. Expansion of the overlying cortex. Soap bubble appearance - The tumor is homogeneously lytic with trabeculae of the remnants of bone traversing it, giving it a loculated appearance called soap bubble appearance. No calcification within the tumor. No or minimal reactive sclerosis around the tumor

Table:

#MANTRA RADIOLOGICAL APPEARANCE TUMORS SUNRAY APPEARANCE /CODMAN’S TRIANGLE OSTEOSARCOMA BUT CAN BE SEEN IN ANY MALIGNANT CONDITION SOAP BUBBLE APPEARANCE GIANT CELL TUMOR ONION PEEL APPEARANCE EWING’S SARCOMA BUT CAN BE SEEN IN ANY MALIGNANT TUMOR GROUND GLASS APPEARANCE/ SHEPHERDS CROOK DEFORMITY FIBROUS DYSPLASIA HOMOGENOUS CALCIFICATION OSTEOGENIC TUMORS FALLEN FRAGMENT SIGN/TRAP DOOR SIGN SIMPLE BONE CYST POLKA DOT SIGN VERTEBRAL HEMANGIOMA MOTH EATEN BONE MULTIPLE MYELOMA WINKING OWL SIGN VERTEBRAL METASTASIS DOUBLE DENSITY SIGN ANEURYSMAL BONE CYST PUNCTATE CALCIFICATION CHONDROBLASTOMA POPCORN CALCIFICATION CHONDROSARCOMA PATCHY CALCIFICATION CHONDROSARCOMA AND CHONDROBLASTOMA Features Giant cell tumour Simple bone cyst Aneurysmal bone cyst Fibrous dysplasia ● Age 20-40 yrs. < 20 yrs. 10-40 yrs. 20-30 yrs. ● Common bones Lower femur, Upper humerus Upper femur Tibia Humerus Neck of the femur Tibia ● Location Epiphysis Metaphysis Metaphysis Metaphysis ● X-ray Soap-bubble appearance, eccentrically placed Maximum width less than width of the growth plate Distending lesion, 'ballooning' the bone Multi-loculated Ground-glass appearance Trabeculations++ ● Treatment preferred Curettage and bone graft Curettage and bone graft Curettage and bone graft

questions.text: Identify the muscle which flexes the leg and medially rotates the leg at knee joint, weakly abduct and laterally rotate at the hip joint: (ORTHOPEDICS)
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sartorius Origin: Anterior superior iliac spine Insertion: Upper part of the medial surface of the shaft of the tibia. Action: Flexes, abducts, laterally rotates thigh at hip joint; flexes and medially rotates leg at knee joint Nerve supply: branches of femoral nerve Movement Target Target motion direction Prime mover Insertion Insertion Medial compartment of thigh Moves back of lower legs up toward buttocks, as when kneeling; assists in opening thighs Femur; tibia/fibula Tibia/fibula: flexion; thigh: adduction Gracilis Inferior ramus; body of pubis; ischial ramus Medial surface of tibia Anterior compartment of thigh: Quadriceps femoris group Moves back of lower legs up toward buttocks, as when kneeling; assists in opening thighs Femur; tibia/fibula Tibia/fibula: flexion; thigh: adduction Gracilis Inferior ramus; body of pubis; ischial ramus Medial surface of tibia Moves lower leg out in front of body, as when kicking Tibia/fibula Extension Vastus medialis Linea aspera; intertrochanteric line Patella; tibial tuberosity Moves lower leg out in front of body, as when kicking; assists in raising the knee Tibia/fibula Tibia/fibula: extension; thigh: flexion Rectus femoris Anterior inferior iliac spine; superior margin of acetabulum Patella; tibial tuberosity Moves lower leg out in front of body, as when kicking Tibia/fibula Extension Vastus lateralis Greater trochanter; intertrochanteric line; linea aspera Patella; tibial tuberosity Moves back of lower legs up and back toward the buttocks, as when kneeling; assists in moving thigh diagonally upward and outward as when mounting a bike Femur; tibia/fibula Extension Vastus medialis Linea aspera; intertrochanteric line Patella; tibial tuberosity Posterior compartment of thigh: Hamstring group Moves back of lower legs up and back toward the buttocks, as when kneeling: moves thigh down and back; twists the thigh (and lower leg) outward Femur; tibia/fibula Tibia/fibula: flexion; thigh: extension, lateral rotation Biceps femoris Ischial tuberosity: linea aspera; distal femur Head of fibula; lateral condyle of tibia Moves back of lower legs up toward buttocks, as when kneeling; moves thigh down and back; twists the thigh (and lower leg) inward Femur; tibia/fibula Tibia/fibula: flexion; thigh: extension, medial rotation Semitendinosus Ischial tuberosity Upper tibial shaft Moves back of lower legs up and back toward the buttocks as when kneeling: moves thigh down and back; twists the thigh (and lower leg) inward Femur; tibia/fibula Tibia/fibula: flexion; thigh: extension, medial rotation Semi- membranosus Ischial tuberosity Medial condyle of tibia; lateral condyle of femur

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B: Adductor longus is a skeletal muscle located in the thigh. One of the adductor muscles of the hip, its main function is to adduct the thigh and it is innervated by the obturator nerve OPTION C: The vastus lateralis is the largest of the four quadriceps muscles in the anterior compartment of the thigh. The others are the rectus femoris, the vastus intermedius, and the vastus medialis. OPTIONS D: The Adductor Magnus muscle is one of hip adductors. The adductor magnus is the largest, most powerful and the most complex of the adductor group.

questions.text: Book test is used to assess the function of adductor pollicis. Which of the following nerve supplies the muscle?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ulnar Nerve A deep terminal branch of the ulnar nerve supplies the adductor pollicis muscle. Froment's sign / Book test is a physical examination of the hand to test for palsy of the ulnar nerve which results in reduced functionality and muscle weakness of the pinch grip. It tests the strength of the adductor pollicis of the thumb , which is innervated by the ulnar nerve and is weakened in ulnar nerve palsy.

Table:

#MANTRA NERVE TEST MUSCLE ULNAR NERVE 1. BOOK TEST 2. CARD TEST 3. FROMENT’S SIGN 4. EGAWA TEST 1. ADDUCTOR POLLICIS 2. PALMAR INTEROSSEI 3. FLEXOR POLLICIS SUBSTITUTES FOR ADDUCTOR POLLICIS 4. 4. DORSAL INTEROSSEI MEDIAN NERVE 1. APE THUMB 2. PEN TEST 3. PINCER GRASP(KILOH NEVIN SIGN) 4. POINTING INDEX(OCHNERS CLASP/BENEDICTION TEST) 1. THENAR MUSCLES 2. ABDUCTOR POLLICIS BREVIS 3. FLEXOR DIGITORUM PROFUNDUS + FLEXOR POLLICIS LONGUS(ANTERIOR INTEROSSEOUS NERVE) 4. FLEXOR DIGITORUM SUPERFICIALIS + LATERAL HALF OF FLEXOR DIGITORUM PROFUNDUS RADIAL NERVE 1. THUMB AND FINGER DROP 2. WRIST DROP 1. EXTENSORS(POSTERIOR INTEROSSEUS NERVE) 2. EXTENSORS OF WRIST

questions.text: You visit a new-born near your house and identify that the child has CTEV. When will you advise the baby’s parents to put on a cast? (First cast application)?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2 weeks of age Ponseti Method : Should begin as early as 2 weeks The order of correction according to Ponseti's method is cavus-adduction-varus-equinus (CAVE) . Weekly manipulation of the foot is done with the help of plaster casts. To begin with, the first metatarsal is elevated to correct the cavus . This creates a flat longitudinal medial border of foot. Then, the forefoot is abducted in the plane of the metatarsals . This everts the hindfoot and corrects the forefoot out of supination. Finally, the equinus is corrected by dorsiflexing the foot at the ankle joint . A percutaneous Achilles' tenotomy is required later for complete correction of the equinus deformity. In addition to the above procedure, the child can be provided with CTEV shoes once the child starts walking to retain correction.

Highyeild:

Features of CTEV shoes: Straight inner border prevents adduction Outer shoe raise prevents foot inversion Absence of heel prevents equinus Used once the deformity is corrected and when the child starts walking, up to 5 years of age

Table:

#MANTRA
